Key Arguments: The Bill infringes on Australians' human rights to freedom of speech and expression.
ACMA will have excessive powers with no right of appeal.
The Bill uses poorly defined terms, making it more suited to a totalitarian regime.
The Bill lacks adequate safeguards or transparency.
The Bill exempts the government from accountability.
The Bill allows media organizations to excessively restrict freedom of speech.
The Bill does not protect individual privacy.
The Bill is undemocratic by excluding government-authorized content from censorship.
The Bill only permits 'registered news organizations' to present government opinions.
The penalties within the Bill are excessive.
Notable Quotes: This Bill extinguishes the rights of Australians to freedom of speech and expression ‘through any media regardless of frontiers.’
This is completely unacceptable in a democratic country such as our own.

Such an extension of power to so few individuals, the lack of any rights to an appeals process, the reliance on the judiciary to hammer out the possible meanings of vague terminologies and the brutal enforcement of heavy fines and possible incarceration of offenders are all features of totalitarian regimes.
The Bill itself poses a ‘threat of undermining the democratic process’.

In all the ways outlined above, the proposed Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 2023 (Combatting Misinformation and Disinformation) is deeply flawed and should be withdrawn by the government with immediate effect.
